awd_titl_txt: 2020 National Science Foundation Cyber-Physical (CPS) Principal Investigators' (PI) Meeting
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this project is to plan and organize the 2020 National Science Foundation (NSF) Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) Principal Investigator (PI) Meeting. This meeting convenes all PIs of the NSF CPS Program for the ninth time since the program began. The PI Meeting is to take place during the Fall of 2020 in Alexandria, Virginia. The PI meeting is an annual opportunity for NSF-sponsored CPS researchers, industry representatives, and Federal agency representatives to gather and review new CPS developments, identify new and emerging applications, and to discuss technology gaps and barriers. The program agenda is community-driven and includes presentations (oral and poster) from PIs, reports of past year program activities, and showcase/pitch new CPS innovations and results.

The annual PI Meeting serves as the only opportunity where the NSF-funded CPS Principal Investigators meet to share their research, discuss new research opportunities and challenges, and explore new ideas and partnerships for future work. Furthermore, the PI meeting is also an opportunity for the academic research community to interact with industry entities and government agencies with vested interest in CPS research and development. The PI Meeting is a forum for sharing ideas across the CPS community. It has played a major role in growing the community across a broad range of sectors and technologies, and performing outreach to others who have interest in learning about the program and participating as future proposers, transition partners, or sponsors. The 2020 PI meeting will feature lightning talks from researchers, poster sessions, special topic workshops, demonstrations and keynotes from leaders in the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic that shuttered most Government agencies and programs in 2020, NSF decided not to hold a CPS PI Meeting that year. The remaining funds from this project were used to support the coordination of the 2021 Virtual CPS that was held Wednesday, June 2- 4, 2021; to support the coordination of the S&CC Virtual PI Meeting that was held April 7-9, 2021; and to defray the cost of the in-person 2022 CPS PI Meeting.

The 2021 CPS PI Meeting represented the 11th such meeting and the first to be held in a virtual format via Hopin technology due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Over a three-day period, the 2021 CPS Virtual PI Meeting brought together 827 stakeholders comprising academia, industry, non-profits, and government who are actively engaged in the CPS program. The program of the meeting included invited keynotes, PI research projects long and short talks, PI research project poster and demonstration sessions, panel discussion about the transition of CPS research-related projects to industry, and breakout sessions. The program was organized by a technical program committee comprising CPS community experts identified by NSF, including Mahnoosh Alizadeh (University of California, Santa Barbara), Andrew Clark (Worcester Polytechnic Institute), Rose Faghih (University of Houston), Lu Feng (University of Virginia), Simone Sylvestri (University of Kentucky), Jules White (Vanderbilt University), and Daphney-Stavroula Zois (University at Albany-SUNY and the VU-ISIS CPS VO project team.

The 2021 S&CC PI Meeting represented the third S&CC PI meeting and the first to be held in a virtual format due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Over a three-day period, the S&CC Virtual PI Meeting had over 660 pre-meeting registrants comprising stakeholders from academia, industry, non-profits, the Japanese academia and government and the US government, who are actively engaged in the CPS program. Of this number, over seventy-five registrants were students.

All public artifacts, including a meeting webcast, website Urls, speaker presentations, position papers, the meeting program, meeting participant lists, and meeting organizers have been disseminated to communities of interest via the public 2021 Virtual CPS PI Meeting website which can be found at https://cps-vo.org/group/cps-pimtg21 and for the 2021 Virtual S&CC PI Meeting at https://cps-vo.org/group/scc-pimtg21.

Details of the 2022 CPS PI Meeting project will be detailed in the NSF Annual Report to NSF later in 2023.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2023
Modified by: Frankie D King
